001package io.jstach.jstachio;
002
003import java.util.function.Function;
004
005import org.eclipse.jdt.annotation.Nullable;
006
007import io.jstach.jstache.JStacheConfig;
008import io.jstach.jstache.JStacheFormatter;
009import io.jstach.jstache.JStacheFormatterTypes;
010
011/**
012 * Formats and then sends the results to the downstream appender.
013 *
014 * Implementations should be singleton like and should not contain state. By default
015 * native types are passed straight through to the downstream appender. If this is not
016 * desired one can override those methods.
017 * <p>
018 * <em>Important: the formatter does not decide what types are allowed at compile time to
019 * be formatted.</em> To control what types are allowed to be formatted see
020 * {@link JStacheFormatterTypes}.
021 * <p>
022 * An alternative to implementing this complicated interface is to simply make a
023 * {@code Function<@Nullable Object, String>} and call {@link #of(Function)} to create a
024 * formatter.
025 * <p>
026 * To implement a custom formatter:
027 *
028 * <ol>
029 * <li>Implement this interface or use {@link #of(Function)}.</li>
030 * <li>Register the custom formatter with {@link JStacheFormatter}.</li>
031 * <li>Add additional allowed types with {@link JStacheFormatterTypes} on to the class
032 * that is annotated with {@link JStacheFormatter}</li>
033 * <li>Set {@link JStacheConfig#formatter()} to the class that has the
034 * {@link JStacheFormatter}.</li>
035 * </ol>
036 *
037 * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the formatter
038 * should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream appender.
039 * @author agentgt
040 * @see JStacheFormatterTypes
041 * @see JStacheFormatter
042 *
043 */
044public interface Formatter extends Function<@Nullable Object, String> {
045
046        /**
047         * Formats an object by using {@link StringBuilder} and calling
048         * {@link #format(Appender, Output, String, Class, Object)}.
049         * @param t the object to be formatted. Maybe <code>null</code>.
050         * @return the formatted results as a String.
051         */
052        @Override
053        default String apply(@Nullable Object t) {
054                var sb = new Output.StringOutput(new StringBuilder());
055                format(Appender.defaultAppender(), sb, "", Object.class, t);
056                return sb.toString();
057        }
058
059        /**
060         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender.
061         *
062         *
063         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
064         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
065         * appender.
066         * @param <A> the appendable type
067         * @param <E> the appender exception type
068         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
069         * directly
070         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
071         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
072         * @param c the object class but is not guaranteed to be accurate. If it is not known
073         * Object.class will be used.
074         * @param o the object which maybe null
075         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
076         */
077
078        <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, Class<?> c,
079                        @Nullable Object o) throws E;
080
081        /**
082         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender. The
083         * default implementation passes natives through to the downstream appender.
084         *
085         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
086         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
087         * appender.
088         * @param <A> the appendable type
089         * @param <E> the appender exception type
090         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
091         * directly
092         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
093         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
094         * @param c character
095         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
096         */
097        default <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, char c)
098                        throws E {
099                downstream.append(a, c);
100        }
101
102        /**
103         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender. The
104         * default implementation passes natives through to the downstream appender.
105         *
106         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
107         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
108         * appender.
109         * @param <A> the appendable type
110         * @param <E> the appender exception type
111         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
112         * directly
113         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
114         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
115         * @param s short
116         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
117         */
118        default <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, short s)
119                        throws E {
120                downstream.append(a, s);
121        }
122
123        /**
124         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender. The
125         * default implementation passes natives through to the downstream appender.
126         *
127         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
128         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
129         * appender.
130         * @param <A> the appendable type
131         * @param <E> the appender exception type
132         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
133         * directly
134         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
135         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
136         * @param i integer
137         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
138         */
139        default <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, int i)
140                        throws E {
141                downstream.append(a, i);
142        }
143
144        /**
145         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender. The
146         * default implementation passes natives through to the downstream appender.
147         *
148         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
149         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
150         * appender.
151         * @param <A> the appendable type
152         * @param <E> the appender exception type
153         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
154         * directly
155         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
156         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
157         * @param l long
158         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
159         */
160        default <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, long l)
161                        throws E {
162                downstream.append(a, l);
163        }
164
165        /**
166         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender. The
167         * default implementation passes natives through to the downstream appender.
168         *
169         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
170         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
171         * appender.
172         * @param <A> the appendable type
173         * @param <E> the appender exception type
174         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
175         * directly
176         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
177         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
178         * @param d double
179         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
180         */
181        default <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, double d)
182                        throws E {
183                downstream.append(a, d);
184        }
185
186        /**
187         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender. The
188         * default implementation passes natives through to the downstream appender.
189         *
190         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
191         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
192         * appender.
193         * @param <A> the appendable type
194         * @param <E> the appender exception type
195         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
196         * directly
197         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
198         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
199         * @param b boolean
200         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
201         */
202        default <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, boolean b)
203                        throws E {
204                downstream.append(a, b);
205        }
206
207        /**
208         * Formats the object and then sends the results to the downstream appender. The
209         * default implementation passes natives through to the downstream appender.
210         *
211         * @apiNote Although the formatter has access to the raw {@link Appendable} the
212         * formatter should never use it directly and simply pass it on to the downstream
213         * appender.
214         * @param <A> the appendable type
215         * @param <E> the appender exception type
216         * @param downstream the downstream appender to be used instead of the appendable
217         * directly
218         * @param a the appendable to be passed to the appender
219         * @param path the dotted mustache like path
220         * @param s String
221         * @throws E if the appender or appendable throws an exception
222         */
223        default <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, String s)
224                        throws E {
225                format(downstream, a, path, String.class, s);
226        }
227
228        /**
229         * Adapts a function to a formatter.
230         *
231         * If the function is already a formatter then it is simply returned (noop). Thus it
232         * is safe to repeatedly call this on formatters. If the function is adapted the
233         * returned adapted formatter does not pass native types to the inputted function.
234         * @param formatterFunction if it is already an escaper
235         * @return adapted formattter
236         */
237        public static Formatter of(@SuppressWarnings("exports") Function<@Nullable Object, String> formatterFunction) {
238                if (formatterFunction instanceof Formatter f) {
239                        return f;
240                }
241                return new ObjectFunctionFormatter(formatterFunction);
242        }
243
244}
245
246class ObjectFunctionFormatter implements Formatter {
247
248        private final Function<@Nullable Object, String> function;
249
250        public ObjectFunctionFormatter(Function<@Nullable Object, String> function) {
251                super();
252                this.function = function;
253        }
254
255        @Override
256        public <A extends Output<E>, E extends Exception> void format(Appender downstream, A a, String path, Class<?> c,
257                        @Nullable Object o) throws E {
258                String result = function.apply(o);
259                downstream.append(a, result);
260        }
261
262}
